title: A comment on Liu and Yau's positive quasi-local mass
abstract: Liu and Yau (Phys.Rev.Lett. 90, 231102, 2003) propose a definition of quasi-local mass for any space-like, topological 2-sphere with positive Gauss curvature (and subject to a second, convexity, condition). They are able to show it is positive using a result of Shi and Tam (J.Diff.Geom. 62, 79, 2002). However, as we show here, their definition can give a strictly positive mass for a sphere in flat space

A Comment on Liu and Yau’s positive quasi-local mass
N.O´ Murchadha∗
Physics Department, University College Cork, Ireland
L.B. Szabados†
Research Institute for Particle and Nuclear Physics, H–1525 Budapest 114, P. O. Box 49, Hungary
K.P. Tod‡
Mathematical Institute, Oxford OX1 3LB, England
In a recent letter to this journal, [1], Liu and Yau pro-
pose a definition of quasi-local mass, which in fact coin-
cides with the ‘quasi-local free energy’ of Kijowski [2], for
any space-like, topological 2-sphere with positive intrin-
sic (or Gauss) curvature. They are then able to prove
positivity of this mass by exploiting a result of Shi and
Tam, [3]. In this Comment we present a simple class of
examples, for which the whole construction is easy to see,
to show that there are space-like, topological 2-spheres in
flat space-time for which this mass is strictly positive.
Kijowski, Liu and Yau restrict consideration to 2-
surfaces Σ with positive intrinsic curvature (and sub-
ject to a second condition, given below). Such a Σ can
be isometrically embedded, uniquely up to isometry, in
flat (Euclidean) 3-space E3 with positive-definite extrin-
sic curvature tensor, and the Kijowski-Liu-Yau definition
of quasi-local energy (equation (105) of [2] and (3) of [1])
is then
EKLY =
1
8piG
∫
Σ
(k0 − k) (1)
where G is Newton’s gravitational constant, k0 is the
trace of the extrinsic curvature of Σ as embedded in E3
and k is given in terms of the Newman-Penrose spin-
coefficients ρ and µ, (see [4] or [5]), as
k =
√
8ρµ. (2)
Kijowski and Liu and Yau require the product ρµ to be
positive for their definition, and this is the second condi-
tion on Σ whose necessity was noted above.
Clearly, (1) will give EKLY = 0 for any Σ which lies in
a space-like hyperplane in flat space-time. However, for
a Σ in flat space-time, with positive intrinsic curvature
and positive ρµ but which does not lie in a space-like
hyperplane, there is no reason to think that EKLY should
vanish, and, as we shall see, it need not.
The idea is to consider a 2-surface which is a cross-
section of the light-cone of the origin in flat space-
time. We introduce standard spherical polar coordinates
(t, r, θ, φ) based at the origin. The future light-cone N
of the origin is given by t = r > 0 and we may define a
topological 2-sphere Σ lying on N by an equation
t = r = F (θ, φ) (3)
for a positive, smooth function F . With a natural choice
of normals to Σ, the relevant spin-coefficients are given
by
ρ =

where ∆ is the Laplacian on the unit sphere. The spin-
coefficient σ is zero (as the light-cone is shear-free) so the
intrinsic curvature K of Σ, calculated from (4.14.20) in
[5], is
K = 2ρµ. (5)
(Note the relation of K to k in equation (2): k = 2

Thus Σ has positive intrinsic curvature and positive ρµ
iff ∆ logF < 1, which is easy to arrange. Suppose this
holds, then following the prescription of Kijowski, Liu
and Yau, we embed Σ into E3, where it will define a con-
vex topological 2-sphere Σ0 with mean curvature say H
and intrinsic curvature K as above. We calculate EKLY
using equations (1), (2) and (5) above to find the expres-
sion

This vanishes for a round 2-sphere (as expected, since in
this case the cross-section of N in fact lies in a hyper-
plane) but is otherwise positive: the Kijowski-Liu-Yau
definition can be strictly positive for space-like, topolog-
ical 2-spheres in flat space-time.
